-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: C. Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...>
Aan: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
Datum: zaterdag 23 maart 2002 23:46
Onderwerp: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Remapping Jerome

Ewout:

Thinks for the tip.  I ran across Softy myself today.  I'm still trying to figure out whether using Softy with Jerome will permit me to attempt a more logical remap of the QWERTY keyboard for QS or whether this is part of the driver?  As a beginner at this, I'm lost.  How does one tell the computer that you want to press two keys, one after the other, and that the screen should then display the appropriate QS character?

The keyman programs can define this. You can download my drivers and open them (the .kmn files) with any normal text editor, and see how it works. Keyman has some good documentation too, from which I learned how to do it.

And the texts you have then made can still be read with the old fonts! So even people who have never heard of Keyman needn't worry.

I would like to get more texts on the Read_Alphabet site, but I don't want to do this until we get a more logical mapping in place.  No point in doing it with the old mapping, which I find horrendous!  However, I would like to have a program that would transliterate (?) from the new mapping back to the old so that people would be able to copy files from the Shavian mapping to a new Jerome mapping and have them still make sense.

I don't think much will be incorrect if you change a text in shavian to the Jerome font. The Jerome and Shavian fonts are meant to be compatible.

I am handicapped in this by being, at best,  semi-computer literate.  I just don't have time to spend learning all this stuff.  At least, not presently.

By the way, I went to your website, which I had not seen.  I appreciate your hard work, and it's good to learn a little more about you.  You are an interesting person.  Thanks to the internet, we can get to know each other.  I have sort of thought of Dutch as being a germanic language somewhat intermediate between English and German.  Is this inaccurate?  Your comment that you had not learned too much German in school surprised me.  I guess I thought German would be easier for a Dutch speaker to learn than it is for an English speaker.

I have found English many times easier than German. In Holland there is English everywhere. We never dub on TV. Always subtitles, except for kiddies who can't read yet. Commercials on TV are 100% English, special terms are English because they sound cooler (even if they have no international character, such as the 'Traffic Information Centre', which reports traffic jams in Holland only on the radio.)

The problem with German is that you never need it, except to show those tourists the way (which is rare too). German words look like Dutch words but mean totally different things. German has explicit indication of cases, something that doesn't occur in Dutch and English. And finally, it has three genders (der, die, das). English has no genders, and Dutch also has three, but merges too (de, het). These genders are not the same in German and Dutch.

Holland is so full of English it doesn't really pose a problem for us. Most Dutch people will understand your English, and if you try to speak Dutch, they will ask you to speak English. But not every Dutch person can speak proper English though. But you will be understood.

I am always discovering mispronunciations in my own speech. And I feel people will easily recognise me as a foreigner because I use different word combinations. But I am understood and I don't know why I would want to hide my origins.

 I have also spent time learning Esperanto.  Can you make your computer show the accents properly.  Their use of "x" after a letter needing an accent just looks so stupid to me.  I expect it is much more difficult to find Esperanto speakers here in the U.S. than it is in Europe.

I don't type that much Esperanto, but you can use 'h' instead of 'x'. Replace the 'h' with the circumflex with a 'k', except for the word 'hxoro', which'll have to become 'koruso'. 'Koro' and 'hxoro' mean two different things.

I am currently playing around with keyman and some Esperanto fonts.

Not too long ago, somebody in the alt.language.artificial newsgroup posted a message on how to write Esperanto with Cyrillic (Russian) characters. I'm also playing around with this. And finally, a specially adapted Shavian for Esperanto also exists, I have a learning book for it. You start to read in Esperanto, and gradually all characters are replaced by their Shavian counterparts. I have made a Quikscript spinoff of this alphabet. I can look up the links if you'd like.

One last point, when I tried connecting to Read_Alphabet on your site, the link did not work.  I am wondering now whether the underline between the two words was included as it must be?

I think I know what it is. I'll fix it.

Paige Gabhart

 Jon:

In the last few days, I've been trying to learn a little something about fonts and keyboard mapping.  I would be interested in having some information regarding the program you used to develop Jerome?  What is it?  Where is it available?  What does it cost?  And does that same program also set up the keyboard mapping?  If you can briefly shed any light on this, I would appreciate it.  Thanks.

I know of a few programs which create fonts. This is a very complicated process (That's how I find it). Look on the web for Softy. An old program which is relatively cheap.

I also know of Macromedia Fontographer, which is very expensive, but used by most commercial organisations.

And there are a few interesting programs available from pyrus.com .

See my website for more info about Keyman, for keyboard remapping: http://teraiten.cjb.net/ and click on quickscript.

Ewout Stam/Teraiten Sovo
